responses.content: As I said to the company, I think it’s a good time to sharpen our focus. Personally, I find moments like these clarifying. It’s a chance to digest and make sure we are working on the right things as a company with – taking a long-term view, making sure we are continuing to invest in deep technology and computer science and doing differentiated work; and gives a chance to assess everything we’re doing with a critical lens; and reallocate resources to our most critical priorities. So it’s a constraint optimization problem. I think it gives us a chance, given a few years of strong growth, to double down and focus, and we’re going to be very disciplined in terms of how we will approach it. But our focus on the long-term areas, be it AI, be it Cloud and other critical areas will continue.

We continue to see a varying set of dynamics across our business, particularly influenced by the macro environment. This includes economic uncertainties, geopolitical factors like the war in Ukraine, and varying impacts across different geographies and verticals. We are optimizing our investments to focus on long-term priorities such as AI and Cloud, ensuring disciplined resource allocation to navigate these uncertainties.

Moments like these allow us to reassess and ensure that our investments in AI and machine learning are aligned with our long-term vision. We are prioritizing areas that offer sustainable value and are willing to reallocate resources to support these critical initiatives. This includes continuing our deep investments in AI, Cloud, and other foundational technologies to drive future growth.

We recognize the potential of Web3 and blockchain technologies and are exploring how Alphabet can contribute meaningfully to this ecosystem. Our Cloud team is investigating ways to support customers in building, transacting, storing value, and deploying new products on blockchain-based platforms. We aim to stay at the forefront of technological innovation by supporting and contributing to emerging technologies like blockchain.

ruth_porat.role: Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer

responses.topic: Ad Business Growth and Economic Uncertainty
responses.content: In terms of the Ad business, I would say, as I did in opening comments, we were very pleased with the year-on-year Search revenue growth in the first quarter, up 24%. And it really reflected the strength that we’ve seen in retail, as Philipp and I commented on. I would say – as you’re asking how are we looking forward, I would say, the revenue growth rates that we delivered in 2021 in Search and across our advertising businesses more generally, as I said in opening comments, did benefit from lapping the COVID-related weakness in 2020. So I think one key point is that we’re not going to have that tailwind for the rest of this year. And as I noted, one of the key areas to focus is Q2 of 2020. That was where we had the largest impact from COVID. So that means in the second quarter of 2022, we’re going to face a tough comp, as I said. I would say, in addition, the second-quarter results are going to continue to reflect that we suspended the vast majority of our commercial activities in Russia. And then I noted the impact of foreign exchange. So as we’re looking at it generally, we feel good about what we’re doing in the business, a couple of key points that I called out there.

The data are complicated. Our results have reflected lapping; continue to reflect lapping of the significant growth rates last year. On top of that, there’s uncertainty in the global economic environment. And then there are issues that differ across industry. You’ve seen it in the news. For some it’s supply chain. For some it’s inventory issues. So we will leave the forecasting to you, and tried to give you sort of the components as we went through Q2 here.

responses.topic: Advertising Revenue Impact from War and ATT
responses.content: We’ve seen pullbacks in spend by some advertisers, which was the biggest factor in the quarter-on-quarter change. The war in Ukraine was a modest headwind to year-on-year and sequential growth. The impact from ATT remained relatively constant, continuing to be a headwind. We are focusing on continuing to invest in YouTube and delivering value to our ecosystem, including users and creators.

At the heart of our capital allocation strategy is investing in long-term growth and driving cash flow to continue investing and returning capital to shareholders. We’ve increased the authorization for share repurchases to $70 billion and are pleased to execute against it. Share repurchases remain a valuable tool in our overall set of investments.

Our subscription businesses, including YouTube TV, YouTube Music, and YouTube Premium, continue to deliver substantial revenue growth driven by subscriber growth. We are pleased with the performance and the ongoing investment in these areas.

responses.topic: Impact of Geopolitical Events on Revenue
responses.content: The war in Ukraine has had a modest impact on our advertising revenues, particularly in Europe and Russia. We suspended the majority of our commercial activities in Russia, which accounted for about 1% of our 2021 revenues, primarily from advertising. Additionally, there was a pull-back in advertiser spend on YouTube in Europe due to the conflict.

We continue to focus on investing for long-term growth while maintaining operational excellence. This includes investing in headcount, technical infrastructure, and enhancing our systems to support product teams. Our hybrid work model necessitates continued investment in office facilities globally, supporting our growing headcount.

philipp_schindler.role: Senior Vice President and Chief Business Officer

responses.content: Performance Max brings together Google’s automation to help advertisers maximize reach and efficiency across our channels. We have introduced new features, including customer acquisition goals, campaign-level insights, and a one-click upgrade tool for Smart Shopping and Local campaigns. We are committed to helping Performance Max deliver maximum value and are focused on generating optimal performance for our advertising partners. Adoption timelines remain consistent with previous rollouts, focusing on delivering maximum value and performance.

Shorts went global and now has 30 billion daily views, four times higher than a year ago. We have launched the YouTube Shorts Fund, available in over 100 countries, with over 40% of creators receiving payments not previously in the YouTube Partner Program. We are also testing ads on Shorts with products like App Install and Video Action campaigns and are encouraged by early results. Our focus is on supporting the next generation of mobile creators and enhancing monetization options.

responses.topic: Composition of Ad Base and Customer Mix
responses.content: We serve a very broad base of customers, including large enterprises and SMBs across various verticals and geographies. Our ad base includes a mix of Fortune 500 companies and newer, smaller businesses. We are not just addressing traditional above-the-line marketing budgets but also tapping into below-the-line budgets like promotional pricing, product placement, and sponsorships. Our main goal is to deliver great experiences for users and drive incremental ROI for advertisers, ensuring their success across all sectors.

We are expanding advertising opportunities on YouTube by integrating shopping capabilities and enhancing direct response options. Features like creator tagging, shopping live streams with brands like Walmart and Target, and product feeds in Video Action Campaigns are in pilot stages. We are also exploring monetization within Shorts and testing how shopping can be integrated with Shorts to drive conversions.

Retail continues to be an important driver of Search revenue. We focus on enabling retailers to adopt omnichannel strategies, removing financial and integration barriers through partnerships with platforms like Shopify, Square, BigCommerce, GoDaddy, and WooCommerce. We have seen strong adoption of Local Inventory Ads and are midway through migrating Smart Shopping campaigns into Performance Max, which has resulted in increased reach and performance for advertisers.

We are committed to privacy-preserving technologies like the Privacy Sandbox to replace third-party cookies. Our latest proposal, Topics API, allows advertisers to show relevant ads based on user interests inferred from browsing behavior in a privacy-preserving manner. This initiative aims to sustain a healthy, ad-supported web while respecting user privacy.

topics: Ad Business Growth and Q3 Outlook

questions.question_text: First, Sundar, just in your letter, you talked about how the economic challenges will serve as an opportunity for Alphabet to deepen its focus and invest for the long-term. I just wanted to get a sense of how that might change the investment profile and the areas of priority for the company.

And then, Ruth, I was hoping you could provide some color, perhaps, on how growth trended more through the second quarter, and if you have any comments on what you’re seeing so far in 3Q in July. Thanks.

Sundar, I just wanted to follow up on the last question a little bit. I think the tone around investment for the year changed somewhat over the course of the last few weeks. We have kind of gone through July and heard about slowing of hiring, and now a reported hiring pause.

You mentioned, just recently, you’re finding moments like these to sort of optimize spend. Can you just talk to – what are you seeing in your business specifically on the advertising side or the Cloud side that is sort of saying – now is when we really do need to make sure we’re optimizing? Are you seeing pull-backs? Or is it more sort of just you’re seeing the macro-economic headlines and wanting to get ahead of it?

You have called out the tougher comps over the last couple of quarters. Can you give us a better sense of how you move away from some of those tougher comps in the periods ahead of us over the next 12 to 18 months? And how maybe we should think about the digestion of the direct response growth and consumption growth that YouTube saw a year ago, and how that might lead to better growth ahead for YouTube in the periods going forward?

And then when you look at the broader competitive landscape for video, how do you think about positioning YouTube short-form video versus long-form video, or enabling creators and businesses to have tools to build their businesses within YouTube? How do you think about product development and aligning the product against the broader competitive landscape?
Has the ramp in Shorts activity been a little bit of a headwind for growth as you ramped that up?

When you think about regulation in Europe, there’s a lot of headlines about the Digital Markets Act and other things. How do you think about the regulatory environment and the evolution over the next couple years?

On Cloud, you mentioned several times Cloud momentum. And I know it was a very tough year-over-year comp, but growth did slow. Wondering if you are seeing any pull-back in new lift-and-shift projects or other new client adds, or if you are seeing a little slowdown in volumes at all?
And then on the margins, is there any urgency to move margins towards breakeven? Or is it still kind of investment mode here with a lot of different products and services to build?
For Sundar, just on Google Cloud, if you could just walk through the next leg of growth, where you’re most excited for the rest of ’22. Thank you.

Ruth, it sounds like there was a good Q4 ad flush, the concept of spend it if you’ve got it. I’m just curious if you could talk about your capital allocation strategy and ultimately how you are thinking about the buy-back.

Philipp, you talked about the beginning of monetizing YouTube Shorts. Do you have any lessons that you’ve drawn so far; or in the long-term is there any view you have on whether that inventory can be better or less monetized than other YouTube inventory that you’ve had traditionally historically?

And then secondly, just on these comments on the pullback by some advertisers, so you talk about strength in Retail and especially in Travel, so what’s left? Does that mean that you’re seeing weakness out of Western Europe in financial verticals and maybe automotive? Any color on which advertisers are pulling back would be helpful.

Can you talk about your ambitions to add more utility to Google Pay so that it becomes a more, hopefully, indispensable service for your user base? And particularly as you hope that this theoretically becomes your next billion-user product.

On YouTube, I think what we’re hearing is that there’s an emerging concern that TikTok is a competitor to YouTube’s mobile position. And I know you call out the strength of Shorts, but if you talk big-picture, are you seeing any meaningful shift in consumer demand for the mobile YouTube product? And any type of advertising, maybe, shift on mobile because of TikTok?
Is there anything you want to call out about Asia Pacific this quarter, why it could have been softer? Or any other product that may have led to a bit of a slower quarter for APAC?

Google Analytics is transitioning to a new version and sunsetting the older version next year. Could you tell us a little bit more about those changes, how they may or may not be related to the deprecation of cookies in Chrome and how you plan to ensure a smooth transition?
You mentioned strong performance in subscriptions, Ruth. Any products that you would highlight that are driving that strength in particular?

If I take your ad dollars, this quarter $50 billion and annualize, it’s like $200 billion a year. Are you or the board focused at all on trying to diversify away from the ad market or do you just feel like there’s so much runway that there is no real reason to stay focused on non-ad-based growth?

topics: Next Billion Users and Product Direction

questions.question_text: Zooming out a little bit on the big picture, Sundar, I think it was almost four years ago when Google released a blog post about the Next Billion Users and how developing products for India and other emerging markets will hopefully, you know, inform what you should be doing everywhere else. So I think you have previously talked about Tez being a pretty notable example there. So can you talk about whether we should continue to be looking overseas to think about what direction you might take across your various products and services?

operating_environment_challenges: Impact of Ukraine war on advertising revenues
Suspension of commercial activities in Russia
Privacy changes affecting advertising spend (e.g., ATT impact)
Regulatory changes in Europe (Digital Markets Act)
